review: Okay, so good things first.- At under fifty dollars, it isn't that expensive. And while the Chromecast and Fire Stick may be even cheaper, the Chromecast has no remote while requiring the use of your phone, and the Fire Stick plays only Amazon Prime content. Which brings me to my second point...- The library of available content providers is impressive. Some you'll obviously need subscriptions to, like Netflix, Hulu, Amazon PRime, et cetera, but there's also a lot of free content on there, too, including PBS. In fact, one of my apps is for the Slingbox, which allows me to watch non-on-demand programming from anythwere my Roku's plugged in. And you can search through all that content--for actors, movie titles, et cetera--from a single search bar.- The shortcuts on the remote make reachign my Netflix and Amazon Prime content even quicker and easier. Which brings me to...The bad.- There is no need for a Blockbuster button on this remote. What should be there is a Hulu button. Or even an HBO Go button. Something someone would actually use. Blockbuster's hanging on by its fingertips. I have no need for that button.- The remote has no headphone jack. This existed on the Roku 3. It's not like they would've had to figure out a whole new system. Just put the headphone jack in. I'd be willing to pay five more dollars for that.- The setup feels like it could've been streamlined.Now, even though I've outlines all my complaints above, I still  haven't subtracted any stars. Because honestly, none of those downsides manage to take away from the awesomeness which is this product. If you're buying for a friend, feel free to get the Chromecast or the Fire Stick or whatever. If you're buying for yourself, get the Roku Stick.
author: Jesse B.

review: I have purchased at least five Roku devices of various types. I love these little things! My daughter is using two (the set up box styles)...one for HDMI and the other with the RCA (red, yellow, white) connectors. She and her kids say the DO NOT miss the [overcharged] subscription service they had. I recommend that users research OTA (over the air) TV before investing in it as it may not be for everyone. However, it saves BOATLOADS of money! Roku apps are available on startup, Netflix, Crackle, and YouTube being among them. Some apps offer access to subscription services, some are free...its up to the user. Many categories of entertainment are indexed, searchable, available at the Roku App Store, and available. Pricing was great, delivery was fast, and packaging was secure.
